description.narrative: The dynamics of conflicts and the field of mediation are in flux and the international community faces challenges in creating new and adapting the existing tools to the changing global environment. While traditional tools like official diplomacy and inter nationally led peace processes and actors like the UN and state actors are still highly relevant, there is need for wiring-up the international peacemaking system to respond to the new challenges and complementing the traditional actors and tools. The fie ld of mediation is undergoing a process of development, to address the accelerating dynamics of internal and transnational conflicts. Globally, the resurgence of power politics has actualised the need for creative approaches to peacemaking, a demand that n on-governmental peace mediation actors are ideally placed to meet. #In sum, there is a widely experienced need for more established and commonly agreed practices and principles that complement the traditional actors and tools of peacemaking. Successful pol icy formation should be nurtured with sharing of good practices and examples from the praxis, in consultation with policymakers and research.#CMI aims to capitalise on its experience and partnerships in order to strengthen international best practices and norms in the field of conflict prevention and resolution. This work will be built around the efforts to enhance understanding and recognition of targeted thematic best practices and lessons, or context/conflict-specific awareness, among the international p eacemaking community, efforts to increase connectivity of various types and levels of actors in exchanges on practice and lessons learned in conflict prevention and resolution, as well as enhancing recognition of best practices based on the legacy of Presi dent Ahtisaari among other actors in the international peacemaking community.
